title: List of diets - Wikipedia
author: Authority control National Japan
cleaned_text: List of diets An individual's [diet](/wiki/Diet_(nutrition)) is the sum of food and drink that one habitually consumes. [Dieting](/wiki/Dieting) is the practice of attempting to achieve or maintain a certain weight through diet. [[1]](#cite_note-1) People's dietary choices are often affected by a variety of factors, including ethical and religious beliefs, clinical need, or a desire to control weight. Not all diets are considered healthy. Some people follow unhealthy diets through habit, rather than through a conscious choice to eat unhealthily. Terms applied to such eating habits include "junk food diet" and "Western diet". Many diets are considered by clinicians to pose significant health risks and minimal long-term benefit. This is particularly true of "crash" or "fad" diets - short-term, weight-loss plans that involve drastic changes to a person's normal eating habits. Only diets covered on Wikipedia are listed under alphabetically sorted headings. Belief-based diets Some people's dietary choices are influenced by their religious, spiritual or philosophical beliefs. [Buddhist diet](/wiki/Buddhist_cuisine): While [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism)does not have specific dietary rules, some Buddhists practice [vegetarianism](/wiki/Buddhist_vegetarianism)based on Mahayana Buddhism's strict interpretation of the first of the [Five Precepts](/wiki/Five_Precepts). [[2]](#cite_note-2) [Hindu diet](/wiki/Diet_in_Hinduism): It is popular for followers of Hinduism to follow [lacto vegetarian diets](/wiki/Lacto_vegetarianism)(though most do not), based on the principle of [ahimsa](/wiki/Ahimsa)(non-harming). [[3]](#cite_note-hindudiet-3)Consuming [beef/cattle](/wiki/Beef)is forbidden or at least taboo among followers due to [cow veneration](/wiki/Cattle_in_religion_and_mythology). Most Hindus in India do intentionally limit their meat consumption one way or another. [[4]](#cite_note-:0-4) [Jain diet](/wiki/Jain_vegetarianism): Due to how the Jain faith interprets [vegetarianism](/wiki/Vegetarianism)is considered mandatory for followers; a lacto-vegetarian diet [[5]](#cite_note-5)or vegan diet [[6]](#cite_note-6)in particular is considered appropriate for Jains. Most Jains also abstain from consuming root vegetables in order to prevent harming insects, worms and microorganisms when they are uprooted. Most also partake in [some form of fasting](/wiki/Fasting_in_Jainism). [[4]](#cite_note-:0-4)Some variants of Jainism further discourage or forbid the consumption of honey, fungi, alcoholic beverages and fermented foods. [Islamic diet](/wiki/Islamic_dietary_laws): Muslims follow a diet consisting solely of food that is [halal](/wiki/Halal)- permissible in Islam. The opposite of halal is [haraam](/wiki/Haraam), food that is Islamically Impermissible. Haraam substances include alcohol, carnivores, pork and other non-ruminant animals, and any meat from an animal which was not killed through the Islamic method of ritual slaughter ( [Dhabiha](/wiki/Dhabiha)). [[7]](#cite_note-7)If an otherwise Halal animal was subject to torture by humans, its meat can still be considered non-permissible for Muslims. [I-tal](/wiki/I-tal): A set of principles which influences the diet of many members of the [Rastafari movement](/wiki/Rastafari_movement). One principle is that natural foods should be consumed. Emphasis is put on consuming produce that is fresh, organic and ideally grown at home or locally. Another principle involves avoiding "unclean" types of food; the definition which is influenced by Biblical teachings. In order to preserve "life energy" Rastafarians encourage [teetotalism](/wiki/Teetotalism), and many Rastafarians interpret I-tal to advocate vegetarianism or veganism as well. [[8]](#cite_note-8)Many followers do view seafood as an acceptable addition to an I-tal diet but they restrict which kinds they permit; fish over a foot long are typically avoided and all shellfish are eschewed as they are not Kosher animals—unlike [finned-fish](/wiki/Actinopterygii)with scales. [Kosher diet](/wiki/Kosher_foods): Food permissible under [Kashrut](/wiki/Kashrut), the set of [Jewish](/wiki/Jewish)dietary laws, is said to be Kosher. Some foods and food combinations are non-Kosher, and failure to prepare food in accordance with Kashrut can make otherwise permissible foods non-Kosher. [[9]](#cite_note-9) [Seventh-day Adventist diet](/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church#Health_and_diet): Combines the [Kosher food](/wiki/Kosher_foods)rules of Judaism with prohibitions against alcoholic beverages and (sometimes) caffeinated beverages. There is emphasis on consuming whole foods. Meat-consumption is heavily discouraged but not necessarily disallowed; about half of Adventists are [lacto-ovo-vegetarians](/wiki/Lacto-ovo_vegetarianism). [[10]](#cite_note-10) [Vegan](/wiki/Veganism#Vegan_diets,_substitutions,_and_meat_analogues)and [pescetarian](/wiki/Pescetarianism)diets are also more popular among Adventists compared to the general public [[11]](#cite_note-11)but other Adventists are still willing to eat Kosher meats. [Word of Wisdom](/wiki/Word_of_Wisdom)diet: The name of a section of the [Doctrine and Covenants](/wiki/Doctrine_and_Covenants), a book of scripture accepted by members of [the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints](/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints). Dietary advice includes (1) wholesome plants "in the season thereof", (2) eating meat sparingly and only "in times of winter, or of cold, or famine", and (3) grain as the "staff of life". [[12]](#cite_note-12)Unlike injunctions against tobacco, alcohol, coffee and tea—compliance with meat-avoidance has always remained optional among [the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints](/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints)and emphasis on refraining from meat has largely been dropped. [[13]](#cite_note-Alexander-13)An official church publication states, "modern methods of refrigeration now make it possible to preserve meat in any season". [[14]](#cite_note-14) - Remba/Lemba diet: [Lemba people](/wiki/Lemba_people)or Remba people are found in Southern Africa and their diet is based on their culture. Their day includes meats and carbohydrates but the meat is slaughtered in a specific way so as to drain maximum blood from the animal. They pay particular attention to cleanliness of the person handling and preparing as well as the utensils used for food. Their diet excludes pork. Calorie and weight control diets A desire to lose weight is a common motivation to change dietary habits, as is a desire to maintain an existing weight. Many weight loss diets are considered by some to entail varying degrees of health risk, and some are not widely considered to be effective. This is especially true of "crash" or "fad" diets. [[15]](#cite_note-15) Many of the diets listed below could fall into more than one subcategory. Where this is the case, it is noted in that diet's entry. Low-calorie diets [5:2 diet](/wiki/5:2_diet): fasting](/wiki/Intermittent_fasting): fasting restriction](/wiki/Calorie_restriction). [[16]](#cite_note-Mattson-16) [Body for Life](/wiki/Body_for_Life_diet): A calorie-control diet, promoted as part of the 12-week Body for Life program. [[17]](#cite_note-17) [Cookie diet](/wiki/Cookie_diet): A calorie control diet in which low-fat [cookies](/wiki/Cookie)are eaten to quell hunger, often in place of a [meal](/wiki/Meal). [[18]](#cite_note-18) [The Hacker's Diet](/wiki/The_Hacker%27s_Diet): Diet by [John Walker](/wiki/John_Walker_(programmer)). The book suggests that the key to reaching and maintaining the desired weight is understanding and carefully monitoring calories consumed and used. [Nutrisystem](/wiki/Nutrisystem)diet: The dietary element of the weight-loss plan from Nutrisystem, Inc. Nutrisystem distributes low-calorie meals, with specific ratios of fats, proteins and carbohydrates. [[19]](#cite_note-19) [Weight Watchers diet](/wiki/Weight_Watchers_(diet)): Foods are assigned point values; dieters can eat any food with a point value provided they stay within their daily point limit. [[20]](#cite_note-20) Very low calorie diets A [very low calorie diet](/wiki/Very_low_calorie_diet) is consuming fewer than 800 calories per day. Such diets are normally followed under the supervision of a doctor. [[21]](#cite_note-21) Zero-calorie diets are also included. [Inedia](/wiki/Inedia)(breatharian diet): A diet in which no food is consumed, based on the belief that [prana](/wiki/Prana)but not food is necessary for human subsistence. [[22]](#cite_note-22) [KE diet](/wiki/KE_diet)(feeding tube diet): A diet in which an individual feeds through a [feeding tube](/wiki/Feeding_tube)and does not eat anything. [[23]](#cite_note-23) [The Last Chance diet](/wiki/The_Last_Chance_Diet): General premise is that the [dieter](/wiki/Dieting)will consume only one low-calorie high protein beverage daily. This equated to no more than 400 calories per day. [[24]](#cite_note-24) [[25]](#cite_note-25) [Tongue Patch Diet](/wiki/Tongue_Patch_Diet): Stitching a [Marlex](/wiki/Marlex)patch to the tongue to make eating painful. Daily calories are then limited to 800 per day maximum in liquid form. Low-carbohydrate diets [Atkins diet](/wiki/Atkins_Nutritional_Approach): A low-carbohydrate the late-20th and early-21st centuries. [[26]](#cite_note-26)Proponents argue that this approach is a more successful way of losing weight than low-calorie diets; [[27]](#cite_note-27)critics argue that a low-carb approach poses increased health risks. [[28]](#cite_note-28)The Atkins diet consists of four phases (Induction, Balancing, Fine-Tuning and Maintenance) with a gradual increase in consumption of carbohydrates as the person goes through the phases. [[29]](#cite_note-29) [Dukan Diet](/wiki/Dukan_Diet): A multi-step diet based on high protein and limited carbohydrate consumption. It starts with two steps intended to facilitate short term weight loss, followed by two steps intended to consolidate these losses and return to a more balanced long-term diet. [[30]](#cite_note-30) [Kimkins](/wiki/Kimkins): A heavily promoted diet for weight loss, found to be fraudulent. [South Beach Diet](/wiki/South_Beach_Diet): Diet developed by the Miami-based cardiologist Arthur Agatston, who says that the key to losing weight quickly and getting healthy is not cutting all carbohydrates and fats from the diet, but choosing the right carbs and the right fats. [[31]](#cite_note-31) [Stillman diet](/wiki/Stillman_diet): A carbohydrate-restricted diet that predates the Atkins diet, allowing consumption of specific food ingredients. Low-fat diets - McDougall's starch diet is a high calorie, high fiber, low fat diet that is based on starches such as potatoes, rice, and beans which excludes all animal foods and added vegetable oils. [John A. McDougall](/wiki/John_A._McDougall)draws on historical observation of how many civilizations around the world throughout time have thrived on starch foods. Crash diets [Crash diets](/wiki/Crash_diet) are [very-low-calorie diets](/wiki/Very-low-calorie_diet) used fast [weight loss](/wiki/Weight_loss). [[32]](#cite_note-32) [[33]](#cite_note-33) [[34]](#cite_note-34) They describe diet plans that involve making extreme, rapid changes to food consumption, but are also used as disparaging terms for common eating habits which are considered unhealthy. This diet is dangerous and can lead to sudden death when not done in a medically supervised setting. [[35]](#cite_note-Isner1979-35) [[36]](#cite_note-Sours1981-36) Several diets listed here are weight-loss diets which would also fit into other sections of this list. Where this is the case, it will be noted in that diet's entry. [Beverly Hills Diet](/wiki/Beverly_Hills_Diet): An extreme diet which has only fruits in the first days, gradually increasing the selection of foods up to the sixth week. [[37]](#cite_note-37) [Cabbage soup diet](/wiki/Cabbage_soup_diet): A low-calorie diet based on heavy consumption of [cabbage](/wiki/Cabbage)soup. Considered a fad diet. [[38]](#cite_note-38) [Grapefruit diet](/wiki/Grapefruit_diet): A fad diet, intended to facilitate weight loss, in which grapefruit is consumed in large quantities at meal times. [[39]](#cite_note-39) [Monotrophic diet](/wiki/Monotrophic_diet): A diet that involves eating only one food item, or one type of food, for a period of time to achieve a desired weight reduction. [Subway diet](/wiki/Subway_diet): A crash diet [[40]](#cite_note-guardiansubway-40)in which a person consumes Subway sandwiches in place of higher calorie fast foods. Made famous by convicted sex offender and former obese student [Jared Fogle](/wiki/Jared_Fogle), who lost 245 pounds after replacing his meals with Subway sandwiches as part of an effort to lose weight. [[40]](#cite_note-guardiansubway-40) Detox diets [Detox diets](/wiki/Detox_diet) involve either not consuming or attempting to flush out substances that are considered unhelpful or harmful. Examples include restricting food consumption to foods without colorings or preservatives, taking supplements, or drinking large amounts of water. The latter practice in particular has drawn criticism, as drinking significantly more water than recommended levels can cause [hyponatremia](/wiki/Hyponatremia). [[41]](#cite_note-41) There is no scientific evidence of any benefit from detox diets, and so they are considered to be [pseudoscientific](/wiki/Pseudoscientific). [[42]](#cite_note-42) [[43]](#cite_note-43) [Juice fasting](/wiki/Juice_fasting): A form of detox diet, in which nutrition is obtained solely from fruit and vegetable juices. The health implications of such diets are disputed. [[44]](#cite_note-44) [Master Cleanse](/wiki/Master_Cleanse): A modified juice fast that substitutes tea and lemonade for food. Diets followed for medical reasons People's dietary choices are sometimes affected by [intolerance](/wiki/Food_intolerance) or [allergy](/wiki/Food_allergy) to certain types of food. There are also dietary patterns that might be recommended, prescribed or administered by medical professionals for people with specific medical needs. [DASH diet](/wiki/DASH_diet)(Dietary Approaches to Stop [Hypertension](/wiki/Hypertension)): A recommendation that those with high [blood pressure](/wiki/Blood_pressure)consume large quantities of fruits, vegetables, whole-grains and low fat dairy foods as part of their diet, and avoid sugar sweetened foods, red meat and fats. Promoted by the [US Department of Health and Human Services](/wiki/US_Department_of_Health_and_Human_Services), a United States government organisation. [[45]](#cite_note-dashguide-45) [Diabetic diet](/wiki/Diabetic_diet): An umbrella term for diets recommended to people with [diabetes](/wiki/Diabetes). There is considerable disagreement in the scientific community as to what sort of diet is best for people with diabetes. [[46]](#cite_note-46) [Elemental diet](/wiki/Elemental_diet): A medical, liquid-only diet, in which liquid nutrients are consumed for ease of ingestion. [[47]](#cite_note-47) [Elimination diet](/wiki/Elimination_diet): A method of identifying foods which cause a person adverse effects, by process of elimination. [[48]](#cite_note-48) [Gluten-free diet](/wiki/Gluten-free_diet): A diet which avoids the protein [gluten](/wiki/Gluten), which is found in barley, rye and wheat. It is a medical treatment for [gluten-related also avoids [casein](/wiki/Casein), a protein commonly found in milk and cheese. This diet has been researched for efficacy in treatment of autism spectrum disorder. [[53]](#cite_note-53) - Healthy kidney diet: This diet is for those impacted with chronic kidney disease, those with only one kidney, those who have a kidney infection and those who may be suffering from some other kidney failure. [[54]](#cite_note-Nutrition-54)This diet is not the dialysis diet, [[55]](#cite_note-55)which is completely different. The healthy kidney diet restricts large amounts of protein, which are hard for the kidney to break down, but especially limits potassium and phosphorus-rich foods and beverages. Liquid intake is often limited as well. [[54]](#cite_note-Nutrition-54) [[56]](#cite_note-56) [Ketogenic diet](/wiki/Ketogenic_diet): A high-fat, low-carb diet, in which dietary and body fat is converted into energy. It is used as a medical treatment for refractory [epilepsy](/wiki/Epilepsy). [[57]](#cite_note-Huffman2006-57) [Liquid diet](/wiki/Liquid_diet): A diet in which only liquids are consumed. May be administered by clinicians for medical reasons, such as after a gastric bypass [[58]](#cite_note-58)or to prevent death through starvation from a hunger strike. [[59]](#cite_note-59) [Low-FODMAP diet](/wiki/Low-FODMAP_diet): A diet that consists in the all fermentable carbohydrates (FODMAPs). [Soft diet](/wiki/Soft_diet) [Specific carbohydrate diet](/wiki/Specific_carbohydrate_diet): A diet that aims to restrict the intake of complex carbohydrates such as found in grains and complex sugars. [[60]](#cite_note-brown-60) Fad diets A [fad diet](/wiki/Fad_diet) is a [diet](/wiki/Dieting) that is popular for a time, similar to [fads](/wiki/Fad) in fashion, without being a standard dietary recommendation, and often promising unreasonably fast weight loss or nonsensical health improvements. [[61]](#cite_note-Hart2018-61) [[62]](#cite_note-Hanky2017-62) [[63]](#cite_note-bda-63) [[64]](#cite_note-Oxford2013-64) [[65]](#cite_note-Zoumbaris2014-65) There is no single definition of what a fad diet is, encompassing a variety of diets with different approaches and evidence bases, and thus different outcomes, advantages and disadvantages, [[62]](#cite_note-Hanky2017-62) and it is ever-changing. [[61]](#cite_note-Hart2018-61) [[62]](#cite_note-Hanky2017-62) Generally, fad diets promise short-term changes with little efforts, and thus may lack educating consumers about whole-diet, whole lifestyle changes necessary for sustainable health benefices. [[61]](#cite_note-Hart2018-61) [[62]](#cite_note-Hanky2017-62) [[66]](#cite_note-Williams2013-66) [[67]](#cite_note-Shick1998-67) Fad diets are often promoted with exaggerated claims, such as rapid [weight loss](/wiki/Weight_loss) of more than 1 kg/week or improving health by "detoxification", or even dangerous claims. [[62]](#cite_note-Hanky2017-62) [[63]](#cite_note-bda-63) [[68]](#cite_note-phn-68) [[69]](#cite_note-katz-69) Since the "fad" qualification varies over time, social, cultural and subjective view, this list cannot be exhaustive, [[61]](#cite_note-Hart2018-61) and fad diets may continue or stop being fads, such as the [mediterranean diet](/wiki/Mediterranean_diet). [[70]](#cite_note-BrownIsaacs2010-70) Some of them have therapeutic indications, such as epilepsy or obesity, [[71]](#cite_note-EatrightKeto-71) [[72]](#cite_note-USGuidelines2013-72) and there is no one-size-fits-all diet that would be a panacea for everyone to lose weight or look better. [[61]](#cite_note-Hart2018-61) [[62]](#cite_note-Hanky2017-62) Dieteticians are a regulated profession that can distinguish diet](/wiki/Food_combining): A nutritional approach where certain food types are deliberately consumed together or separately. For instance, some weight control diets suggest that proteins and carbohydrates should not be consumed in the same meal. [[81]](#cite_note-sophisticated-81) [Fit for Life diet](/wiki/Fit_for_Life): Recommendations include not combining protein and carbohydrates, not drinking water at meal time, and avoiding dairy foods. [[82]](#cite_note-gale-82) [[83]](#cite_note-famdoc-83) [Fruitarianism](/wiki/Fruitarianism) [[84]](#cite_note-84) [Gluten refer to the eating habits of humans during the [Paleolithic](/wiki/Paleolithic)era, or of modern dietary plans purporting to be based for the purpose of weight loss instead of in which a person attempts to split calorie intake from carbohydrates, proteins and fats in a 40:30:30 ratio. [Breatharian diet](/wiki/Inedia): A diet based on a belief that people can sustain with spirituality and sunlight alone, but leads to starvation and devotees have been spotted eating and drinking in diet based on a belief A vegetarian diet is one which excludes meat. Vegetarians also avoid food containing [by-products](/wiki/By-products) of [animal [Fruitarian consists of raw fruit. [[143]](#cite_note-143) [Lacto vegetarianism](/wiki/Lacto_vegetarianism): A vegetarian diet that includes certain types of dairy, but excludes eggs and foods which contain animal [rennet](/wiki/Rennet). [[144]](#cite_note-bbcvegetarian-144)A common diet among followers of several religions, including [Hinduism](/wiki/Hinduism), [Sikhism](/wiki/Sikhism)and [Jainism](/wiki/Jainism), based on the principle of [Ahimsa](/wiki/Ahimsa)(non-harming). [[3]](#cite_note-hindudiet-3) [Ovo vegetarianism](/wiki/Ovo_vegetarianism): A vegetarian diet that includes eggs, but excludes dairy. [Ovo-lacto vegetarianism](/wiki/Ovo-lacto_vegetarianism): A vegetarian diet that includes eggs and dairy. [[144]](#cite_note-bbcvegetarian-144) [Vegan diet](/wiki/Veganism): In addition to the abstentions of a vegetarian diet, vegans do not use any product produced by animals, such as eggs, dairy products, or honey. [[142]](#cite_note-vegetarian-142)The vegan philosophy and lifestyle is broader than just the diet and also includes abstaining from using any products tested on animals and often campaigning for [animal welfare](/wiki/Animal_welfare)and [animal rights](/wiki/Animal_rights). Semi-vegetarian diets [Semi-vegetarianism](/wiki/Semi-vegetarianism): A predominantly vegetarian diet, in which meat is occasionally consumed. This includes "flexitarian", [reducetarian](/wiki/Reducetarian_Foundation)and [demitarian](/wiki/Demitarian)diets [[145]](#cite_note-145)Sometimes semi-vegetarian and flexitarian diets are defined as distinct from one another, where the former is defined as abstaining from red meat while the latter simply entails only eating meat infrequently. [[146]](#cite_note-146) [[147]](#cite_note-147) [[148]](#cite_note-148) [Pescetarianism](/wiki/Pescetarianism): A diet which includes [seafood](/wiki/Seafood), but not poultry, other white meat or [meat from mammals](/wiki/Red_meat). [Pollotarianism](/wiki/Pollotarianism): A diet which includes [poultry](/wiki/Poultry), but no other white meat, seafood or meat from mammals. [Kangatarian](/wiki/Kangatarian): A diet originating from Australia. In addition to foods permissible in a vegetarian diet, [kangaroo](/wiki/Kangaroo)meat is also consumed. [[149]](#cite_note-149)The name is a [protologism](/wiki/Protologism)that may have started out as a joke rather than a dietary term or identifying label that was ever intended to be taken seriously or used unironically. [[150]](#cite_note-150) [Planetary health diet](/wiki/Planetary_health_diet): Dietary paradigms that have the following aims: to feed a growing world's population, to greatly reduce the worldwide number of deaths caused by poor diet, and to be environmentally sustainable as to prevent the collapse of the natural world. [[151]](#cite_note-151) [Plant-based diet](/wiki/Plant-based_diet): A broad term to describe diets in which animal products do not form a large proportion of the diet. Under some definitions a plant-based diet is fully vegetarian; under others it is possible to follow a plant-based diet whilst occasionally consuming meat. [[152]](#cite_note-US_News_&_World_Report_Health-152) Other diets [Alkaline diet](/wiki/Alkaline_diet): The avoidance of relatively acidic foods - foods with low [pH](/wiki/PH)levels - [caffeine](/wiki/Caffeine), [dairy](/wiki/Dairy), [fungi](/wiki/Fungi), [grains](/wiki/Food_grain), [meat](/wiki/Meat), and [sugar](/wiki/Sugar). a diet may have health benefits; [[153]](#cite_note-153)critics consider the arguments to have no scientific basis. [[154]](#cite_note-154) [Clean eating](/wiki/Clean_eating) [Climatarian diet](/wiki/Climatarian_diet): A diet focused on reducing the [carbon footprint](/wiki/Carbon_footprint)of the consumed food, particularly through the consumption of [locally sourced food](/wiki/Local_food)and the avoidance of beef and lamb meat. [[155]](#cite_note-155)Adherents may also be "organivores" (strong [intensively diet](/wiki/Eat-clean_diet): Focuses on eating foods without preservatives, and on mixing lean proteins with complex carbohydrates. [[157]](#cite_note-157) [Gerson therapy](/wiki/Gerson_therapy): A form of [alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine), the diet is low salt, low fat and vegetarian, and also involves taking specific supplements. It was developed by [Max Gerson](/wiki/Max_Gerson), who claimed the therapy could cure cancer and chronic, degenerative diseases. These claims have not been scientifically proven, and they can cause serious illness and death. [[158]](#cite_note-ACS-158) [The Graham Diet](/wiki/The_Graham_Diet): A vegetarian diet which promotes whole-wheat flour and discourages the consumption of stimulants such as alcohol and caffeine. Developed by [Sylvester Graham](/wiki/Sylvester_Graham)in the 19th century. [[159]](#cite_note-159) [Hay diet](/wiki/Hay_diet): A food-combining diet developed by [William Howard Hay](/wiki/William_Howard_Hay)in the 1920s. Divides foods into separate groups, and suggests that proteins and carbohydrates should not be consumed in the same meal. [[81]](#cite_note-sophisticated-81) [High-protein diet](/wiki/High-protein_diet): A diet in which high quantities of protein are consumed with the intention of building muscle. Not to be confused with low-carb diets, where the intention is to lose weight by restricting carbohydrates. [High residue diet](/wiki/High_residue_diet): A diet in which high quantities of [dietary fiber](/wiki/Dietary_fiber)are consumed. High-fiber foods include certain fruits, vegetables, nuts and grains. [[160]](#cite_note-mayoclinic-160) [Inuit diet](/wiki/Inuit_diet): [Inuit](/wiki/Inuit)traditionally consume food that is fished, hunted or gathered locally, predominantly meat and fish. [[161]](#cite_note-161) [Jenny Craig](/wiki/Jenny_Craig): A weight-loss program from Jenny Craig, Inc. It includes weight counselling among other elements. The dietary aspect involves the consumption of pre-packaged food produced by the company. [[162]](#cite_note-162) [Locavore diet](/wiki/Locavore_diet): a [neologism](/wiki/Neologism)describing the eating of food that is locally produced, and not moved long distances to market. An example of this was explored in the book [100-Mile Diet](/wiki/100-Mile_Diet), in which the authors only consumed food grown within 100 miles of their residence for a year. [[163]](#cite_note-163)People who follow this type of diet are sometimes known as [locavores](/wiki/Locavore). [Low carbon diet](/wiki/Low_carbon_diet): Consuming food which has been produced, prepared and transported with a minimum of associated [greenhouse diet in which processed food is avoided. Common components include grains, beans and vegetables. [[164]](#cite_note-164) [Mediterranean diet](/wiki/Mediterranean_diet): A diet based on habits of some southern European countries. One of the more distinct features is that olive oil is used as the primary source of fat. [[165]](#cite_note-165) [MIND diet](/wiki/MIND_diet): combines the portions of the DASH diet and the Mediterranean diet. The diet is intended to reduce neurological deterioration such as Alzheimer's disease. [[166]](#cite_note-Marcason_2015-166) [Montignac diet](/wiki/Montignac_diet): A weight-loss [glycemic calorie diet](/wiki/Negative_calorie_diet): A claim by many weight-loss diets that some foods take more calories to digest than they provide, such as celery. The basis for this claim is disputed. [[168]](#cite_note-168) [Okinawa diet](/wiki/Okinawa_diet): A low-calorie diet based on the traditional eating habits of people from the [Ryukyu Islands](/wiki/Ryukyu_Islands). [Omnivorous diet](/wiki/Omnivore#Etymology_and_definitions): An omnivore consumes diverse range plant and animal-based food. [[169]](#cite_note-169) [Organic food diet](/wiki/Organic_food): A diet consisting only of food which is organic - it has not been produced with modern inputs such as synthetic [fertilizers](/wiki/Fertilizer), A meal replacement served in some United States prisons to inmates who are not trusted to use cutlery. Its composition varies between institutions and states, but as a replacement for standard food, it is intended to provide inmates with all their dietary needs. [Raw foodism](/wiki/Raw_foodism): A diet which centres on the consumption of uncooked and unprocessed food. Often associated with a vegetarian diet, [[171]](#cite_note-171)although some raw food dieters do consume A diet around consuming "power foods" [SparkPeople diet](/wiki/SparkPeople) [Sugar Busters!](/wiki/Sugar_Busters!): Focuses on carbohydrates, particularly sugars. [[173]](#cite_note-173) [Western pattern diet](/wiki/Western_pattern_diet)(WPD): 'Default' diet in many [developed countries](/wiki/Developed_countries), the [Anglosphere](/wiki/Anglosphere). The name is from " [Western world](/wiki/Western_world)" and is interchanged with "standard American diet" and "meat-sweet diet" due to the high amount of meat (total), red meats (particularly), dairy, [sweets](/wiki/Confectionery)and refined cereals. [[174]](#cite_note-174)Subpar intake of whole grains, legumes, tree nuts, produce and seafood is the norm.
